Description: Fragmentary limestone figure of an official, only the right-side portion of the body and base now intact. The figure’s right leg is cloaked and laid flat, suggesting that he adopted a cross-legged position. Much of the body is now lost. Two lines of continuous text are inscribed around the statue base, both beginning at the front of the base. These are two offering formulae based on their opening lines, and on the right side this continues with a dedication to Hathor, Mistress of Thebes. The left side of the figure and base has been broken off, and both right corners of the statue base are also damaged. The object is now supported on a thick modern base.
Curator's comments: The dedication to Hathor and evocation of the Theban area may indicate the object’s original provenance. The fragment of the inscription across the rear right corner of the base is reconstructed by Kitchen (1989) as the name of the individual, Qaha, who has been associated with the area of Deir el-Medina. Further Bibliography: K.A. Kitchen, 1989. Ramesside Inscriptions: Historical and Bibliographical Vol 7, p. 199.
Published Kitchen, Ram. Insc. Vol 7 p199
